dreaded 8 am right it is right yeah so I'm kind of curious from that

I get frequently Asked is you know given that we talk about AI a lot we also um
I'm involved in some sort of analytics things and then my job title is data
scientist actually but I get asked a lot what is data science and how is it
different from some of these other things maybe uh analytics or business intelligence things that that people
talk about and I realize that's a hard question because there's so many different answers to that and it really
depends and there there's a full spectrum I was wondering from your perspective as you talk to students how
do you explain what data science is how do you view its kind of main components
I guess so there's two different ways I like to think about it on one hand if
familiar with Drew Conway's ven diagram of data science it's where you know one of the circles in the ven diagram is
like math and statistics one of the circles is computer science or programming skills or hacking skills and
then the third circle is subject matter expertise and so oftentimes data science
is represented as the intersection of those three things the math stats the computer programming and the subject
matter expertise and I like that but I do think we need to get beyond that a
little bit and think of it more as the union of these three things and the
reason that I say that is I think that when it comes to data science depending on why you're doing it or what your
purpose is you may not need to be an expert in programming or you may not
need to be an expert in statistics or you may be able to not know innately or
as intimately the subject matter expertise that you're working with as an example there are plenty of people doing
data science related things in Excel I would call that data science there's a lot of people who may you know kind of
turn up their noses at it and I I think it's important to if you want to get into data science as a professional
field that you should be able to have tools in your toolkit that are more sophisticated than Excel but it's
certainly possible to do data science in Excel if that's where you or your organization are kind of at that gets me
into kind of the the second definition or description of data science that that I personally use and it's just that data
science I think is using data to make a more informed decision than if you were
to not use that data and I like that because I think it's simple I think it's easy to understand we're just trying to
use data to better inform the decisions and the choices and everything that we make and I think that that's a very
flexible definition that applies to a lot of the things kind of like you mentioned analytics and business
intelligence and all of that I think the distinction between those or among the is fairly arbitrary and it depends on
different companies and what they want there's all sorts of incentives there largely centered around how much they pay people you might be able to pay
people less if they are analysts or bi analysts than if they were data scientists for example but I think that
at the end of the day I just think of data science as let's use data to make a more informed decision than we otherwise
would be making uh if we didn't have that data or if we didn't use it so you know you raised a really great point
there when you're talking about kind of the the different levels that people are engaging in data science from you know
kind of starting maybe at that Excel level and moving up to very sophisticated uh applications and as we
have seen in the last few years this fi just absolutely explode not only in
terms of applications but in terms of the number of roles and people are kind of engaging in data science or finding
it at different levels how has that kind of fragmentation of a rapidly expanding field resulted in you know in looking at
it from different skills in terms of different practitioners needing different levels of expertise and
different skill sets to fulfill their own roles with so many roles out there now I think that a lot of this is driven
by just I mean you're right you know because this field has exploded because there's such a demand for people who can
make sense of numbers and of data um I think that there are so many people kind of aiming to get into this market and so
I know that for example colleges universities are uh are doing their best to better prep people to leave and go
out into the workforce there are organizations like you know my company general assembly where you know our
mission is to empower people to pursue the work they love we want to focus on 21st century skills and we recognize
that there's a skills Gap there that exists and there's a lot of people who want to be able to fill in that skills

there are also employers themselves who say let's try and figure out how we can

we for example reach out to General Assembly and say hey can you train our team specifically to level them so
there's a I think a lot of different Avenues there and based on the of these
different organizations and and what people are working with Etc you'll notice that fragmentation exists perfect
example people who are trained at colleges and universities in statistics and data science will more frequently
come from our backgrounds or maybe data than using Python and I think that there
are a number of things for that but it largely gets back to the types of problems that people in Academia tend to
be solving and how those tend to be more formal and statistical in nature than a lot of the other work people are doing
in data science whereas I think that coming from industry if people jump into data science from industry you're often
working in Excel perhaps you're working in Tableau maybe You Learn Python and I
think python is commonly a language of choice for a lot of them because those people they spend a lot of their day
cleaning and munging data and so I think that in my opinion python is is pretty good at that you notice this kind of
everybody comes in with all of these different perspectives and these different different incentives and goals so everybody is in this big universe of
data scientists however everybody got there through a a very very different path and has very different skills as a

conversation about the skills that people are acquiring how they're acquiring them and and all that I was
wondering if you could kind of give us a glimpse as to some of the main tasks
that data scientists do and how AI fits into that so because we are practical AI
I want to want to make sure and make that connection because um it it is confusing like you said like I know some

their company and then others like you say who maybe they're not running tensor
flow they're running you know Excel or something like that you know how does AI fit into the tasks that data scientists
are typically approaching yeah so I think that to address the first question
when it looks when you say like what are the types of tasks and things that the data scientists are doing in their jobs
those vary quite wildly uh and I I think that there are a lot of I mean again it
depends on the the needs of your company or the needs of your organization and the backgrounds that people have Etc but
one thing that people are fairly surprised to hear is that as a data scientist especially at the entry level
a significant portion of your time is spent cleaning and Gathering and and exploring your data and often thrown out
figure I don't know how rooted this is in like actual evidence but a lot of people ballpark the amount of their time
in a project spent on Gathering and cleaning and exploring their data at about 80% yeah I would second that and I
know Chris and I have talked a couple times on here and I I actually enjoy that part of my job a lot of people seem
to think it's really unenjoyable but he's kind of sick and that way it's funny that you bring that up
cuz it's uh a lot of people don't get into data science to do that everybody gets excited by and connecting with the
other part of your question the artificial intelligence part people get really turned onto the idea of neural
networks and saying I want to learn how to build a neural network and that's that's great I think that neural
networks can and it's not just me thinking this it's true neural networks can be used to solve a great many
problems I also think that in order to be able to build those you've got to
start out with with kind of the basics and understanding all of those inputs because as you and I know as
practitioners of this if your data isn't good it doesn't matter if you crafted or
if you selected the world's greatest neural network it's not going to do what you want it to do and so I I think that
it is surprising to many people getting into the field how much time is spent on that exploratory data analysis but how
it's so important to understand how critical that is to everything that comes afterward that's an interesting
misconception that I think people have when they're kind of thinking of the the kind of the sexy thing that they're you
know that they hey I'm going to go in and do neural networks and Ai and all that and we know that so much of it is
in data cleaning and other kind of mundane tasks can you kind of talk about some of the other common misconceptions
that we tend to experience as we become practitioners in this versus what maybe our expectations would have been upfront
sure I think that probably the other biggest misconception at least what I see from students that that have come in
on day one and who know sort of the broad idea of data science but the inner workings I mean that that's why they're
coming to General Assembly to learn a lot of that and this is certainly not a everybody comes in with this misconception but something that people
are somewhat surprised to learn is how much data science you can do without getting into that artificial
intelligence or that neural network kind of level of of doing data science and when I use the term artificial
intelligence what I mean is we're trying to get computers to mimic or to simulate
human intelligence I think that people are surprised when we teach models like
a linear regression model for listeners who may not have heard of a linear regression model you may have heard of the term line of best fit in the past
where you've just got kind of a a scatterplot of data points and we need to put a line through that data or
thinking about a slightly more complicated model but a related one a logistic regression model where you're
using a curve of best fit to try and predict a one zero outcome for example
for my political experience uh will this person Vote or won't they I think that the misconception for a lot of people or
a misconception is that people often think that neural networks will be the solution to all of their problems when
in reality linear regression logistic regression much more basic techniques
for lack of better word are really really helpful and are often the solution to the problem that you're
trying to solve you make a great point there cuz I'm always telling people don't start with a neural network cuz
there's quite a bit of expense in a variety of ways to to doing that start with the thing that will solve it that
is the cheapest uh mechanism and I think that that gets to the to the heart of data science our goal is to be able to
solve problems very few of us are doing data science just for the sake of doing data science we're not building neural
networks just because we want to build neural networks now I think building neural networks is cool like don't get me wrong but at the same time like when
we are paid an organization uh we're paid to solve problems not to do data science just for the fun of it and so
it's really important to always keep that in mind and I think that's probably the last misconception that I'll bring up is that a lot of times people maybe
it's not a misconception but people often lose the force for the trees and they focus so much on the modeling
technique that they're using and then forget that the reason that they're
using that modeling technique is to try and solve a problem and get a more complete pict picture of the world

so Matt as we kind of ended up talking about the AI side of things and how
that's integrating with data science and also how you know there's been this sort of explosion of roles and diversity in
data science I was wondering as you've kind of taught data science over the years how has the toolkit that you're
teaching and that a lot of people are using for data science how has that kind of shifted or changed over time and I
mean in the sense of you know have things become more standardized less standardized also as opposed to maybe a
few years ago are you having to teach like tensorflow and gpus now or uh you
know whereas maybe before it was like pandas and and scikit learn or or is it both and also like how has the quality
of that toolkit changed as you've been been teaching it in terms of its robustness and integrity and all that
yeah so all really good questions I think that in terms of the the toolkit
continues to evolves so we I guess let me lay the groundw first uh the program that I teach is a 12we Monday through
Friday 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 pm class so it's a full-time 12-week immersive program designed to take people from
I'll call it approximately square one where on the first day we're talking about things like data types we're
talking about control flow and what's the difference between a for Loop and a while loop and all of that stuff in
Python two at the end of week six students are presenting a project I like
to call it the Reddit project where they choose two subreddits of their choice
they use the Reddit API or they will scrape thousands of postings from two
different subreddits and then they will use NLP or natural language processing techniques to parse those out then they
will train a classification model to get the computer to understand if you gave it a new post it would be able to tell
you does that come from subreddit a or subreddit B and it's really cool to see
how quickly people grow with that and then you know that's the halfway point in our class and then people just kind
of Skyrocket from there so that's a little bit of of background in terms of the program that we teach in terms of
the toolkit that we're using given the python stack and focused on pandas andsit learn and stats models and all of
that those Continue to update um I think pandas is it 1.0.0 just was released
recently those continue to evolve and so we're staying on top of those changes as
they go we have also expanded the amount of content that we've had for example
deep learning we Ed to have one twoh hour lesson on neural networks just
because three and a half years ago that was something that was not expected to be seen in like an intro level data
science role uh it was just kind of it was good to show people neural networks but uh it was not reasonable that people
were going to be fitting neural networks in that entry level role and I will say in most cases certainly not all but in
most cases to now we've expend we've extended that to a full week of the class so we are continually changing
that in response to a couple of things one what we see as the instructor and
what we see as our product team as the industry changes and develops and two
what we're also seeing from our alumni people graduate and they say hey this is what I'm focused on in my job these are
the things that that were most helpful you know this is what if you were to change things again in the future these
are the things that you should perhaps include more of moving forward so Matt you you kind of a moment ago were you
you talked about the course that you teach the 12we kind of completely full-time immersive course which raises
the question of there there so many different ways these days of engaging in education to fit people's needs to fit
their Lifestyles and such as that so how are you seeing people engage in those
different ways how does General Assembly fit into that and in what could you just
kind of describe as you see it you know being in that space how you see the options that are available for people
out there yeah of course so I think that when let so we were talking um before
the break about people who want to get into into the field and kind of the options they have some people may go to
a college or a university some people may go to a general assembly some people may be trained by their company in some
way or they may self-study uh there's a lot of different options out there and I think that it all comes down to a couple
of dimensions for most people I think that people think about the time investment people think about the
monetary investment I think people also think about it related to that monetary
investment the opportunity cost for examp if they were to leave work and go to General Assembly or if they left work
to go to grad school or if they went to grad school at night and then also the the practicality of the skills that
they're doing the Hands-On nature of the of the program where I personally think
that General Assembly sets itself apart is it provides like I said this three-month program to take people from
approximately square one to be well-qualified for entry-level data
science roles and people are often able to get more senior roles depending on their backgrounds coming in I think that
a great deal of that has to do with the applied nature of our program I think when you ask where GA fits into
everything I think General Assembly fits into it just because of its applied nature uh like I shared earlier I did a
master's degree in statistics and I learned a ton of really good and important things in my master's
program and at the same time there were a lot of things that were not as applied
as I would have liked them to to be as an example I can't recall working with any data that was missing in my grad
program I'm sure that you both recognize how much missing data we deal with on
literally a daily basis in the practice of data science and how we choose to deal with that is a problem and is a is
a challenge for us I think that with minimal exception the largest data set
that we worked with in grad school was probably about 200 rows whereas that's
not the case uh in in most data science roles um you know everything was already
sanitized and we just focused on building a model instead of thinking about everything else that goes into it
so all of that is to say I think where GA fits into that is for people who say look I I want to commit to learning
skills perhaps I need more of that personal uh oversight isn't the right word but maybe somebody says look I
don't have the the responsibility to do that myself like I don't know if I could sit down and learn data science on my
own start to finish and so I need some support in getting there um and for people who are looking for specifically
practically applied skills um I think that that's sort of the where General Assembly fits in the broader landscape
of things so kind of as a as a followup to that I'm kind of curious uh uh and
I'm thinking a little bit selfishly myself now you know you have people obviously who who are working full-time
and they're just getting into data science or they're fairly early on and you have people like like Daniel and me
who do this for a living but we're in a f fast moving field that's constantly evolving and we're constantly uh you
know leveling ourselves up as this continues on what are some of the options for people who are working full-time have families to support that
they can do what what do you recommend and you know what are those options for us to do I think that if for example
leaving a job as a non-starter which I think it is for many people I think that the best options that are out there
might be either looking at a graduate degree part-time in the evening or on
weekends or something like that or self-study the biggest challenges that I've identified with those for example
if if somebody goes to grad school at night it just takes way longer again it's a trade-off that time and that
money we see at GA people will be willing to say look I'll step back from work for three months and get a job it
you know toward the goal of being able to shorten that amount of time between you know now and when I would be able to
get those new skills I also and I think for people you know on the other end who say look I'm just going to study on my
own I'm not going to commit to a graduate program that might cost however much money I'm going to study on my own
it can just be difficult I mean there's so many data science resources out there to understand what's the right thing to
try and learn and when and how it fits into the broader picture um it can be
quite challenging to do that certainly not impossible but I think that those are probably the two I'll say easiest
options or the best options for people who are currently working full-time one caveat or one other thing that I I will
share and I promise I'm not trying to turn this into a general assembly ad or anything like that but there are also
like part-time classes available in the evenings so there's for example a part-time python class there's a
part-time data science class those certainly don't go in as much depth as you would see in the full-time class but
if you say I'm not able to leave a job but I want to get that Baseline set of skills that will give me a a good enough
starting point where I can jump off and then start learning more on my own that's something that I think is
available to you as well so I'm curious after doing some teaching myself in in
industry and in University a bit as well I know one of the challenges that I've faced in the past is you know
standardizing a data science or AI related curriculum for people with
varied number of of backgrounds so I was curious how do you approach that in the
work that you've done over the years and how have you seen like some people like
you said might come into the beginning of a program and they're already python experts right so learning about a for
Loop or a while loop that's going to be they're not going to struggle with that they may struggle with other bits that is on the other hand easy for people
that already know maybe a bunch of math or or something like that so how do you go about standardizing that sort of
curriculum when there's so many people coming from so many different backgrounds into data science yeah so
one of the things that we do is there's a a certain level of pre-work required
in order to get everyone to kind of a a similar starting point on day one for
those people who are python experts it's I will broadly say that the the programming piece for them is going to
be quite easy there and they can kind of blow through it and not need to worry about their ability on day one um we do
things quite quickly so by the end of for example day two people are I'm
trying to remember the exact like the flow of things by the end of day two people are writing functions and doing
list comprehensions in Python which is still going to be very basic for people who know that coming in but we condense
it down because it is an immersive program we've got 12 weeks and we say look let's make the absolute best of those 12 weeks so our pre-work is in and
attempt to get folks who may not be at that level yet to prepare before the program so that're they're at that level
then on day one we say look we're going to talk about data types it's going to be quick you know make sure to to follow
along we're going to work with you we give people support along the way of course however we move at a pace such
that if you do come in with that that advanced python background we're getting into statistics and distributions and
all of that by like day three or day four so it's not a very long time that people tend to if you come in with that
great python background that people say oh okay like I'm bored or I you know this is not as challenging as I thought
it would be we get through that pretty quickly I'm wondering so one of the questions that I get asked a good deal
from companies that I'm advising with and that sort of thing is like what sort of person should I hire for a data
science position that maybe isn't a data scientist now but they could grow into
one and you know this is similar to what you're talking about there's people that come from a lot of different backgrounds
and maybe they can grow into a data science position or maybe they can there's a lot of different backgrounds
that can go into your general assembly program and that sort of thing I was wondering from your perspective to kind
of help my understanding of that are there certain backgrounds that you feel like lend themselves very well to
quickly adapting to the data science world I guess from my perspective what I've told people in the past is you know
if you're hiring someone in your company maybe maybe it would be best to train up you know the sort of engineers in in
your company to grow into Data scientists because they at least know like they're used to building things and
you know thinking about product thinking about testing thinking about robustness and a lot of times I see people
struggling with that bit in the data science world even after becoming a data scientist so I see those people as
having an advantage from that perspective but I know that I've also known people with a philosophy
background that that have uh you know do amazing things and still have a level of practicality so do you have any insight
on that yeah I think you're absolutely right certainly if somebody has a computer science background I think all
else held equal they will tend to be better at adapting if they need to learn
a new language or change the way that they're using python to focus more on a data science thing I think that if
somebody comes from a a math background they will have an easier time with
understanding some of those statistical and probabilistic Concepts that lay the foundation for data science and are very
important at the same time when you talk about you know the person who has a philosophy background who does well we
see some of the strongest students we've had have come from very very different backgrounds chemistry journalism English
law uh it's certainly not limited to folks who just have a math background or
just have a CS background or something like that when it comes to thinking about within your company I would agree
with you that it can be better uh and obviously your circumstances are
particular to you but in many cases it can be better to train someone up internally and upskill them or res skill
them depending on what it is you want to do for example you might take a programmer and you may say look you know
python this well we want to extend your knowledge of python so you might upskill them and give them that additional skill
or you might take someone who knows the business really well maybe somebody is a financial analyst within your company
Works in Excel most days doesn't have a programming background doesn't really know the math or the stats but you say you know what you know the business or
the organization well enough that you are Well Suited to shift into this so
let's res skill you and give you a whole new set of skills that are fairly foreign to you but given your knowledge
of the business and given your knowledge for those problems that we're solving again it comes back to the fact that data science is really just us using
data to solve problems you know it can be easier to perhaps upskill or
reskilled financial point of view it tends to be more economical to do that I
don't know the statistics and I I've numbers on them and I'm sure that we could find them and share them out afterward but it is generally much more
expensive to hire someone new as well as riskier to hire someone new from the
outside for a role than to train someone up internally um and that your mileage
is going to vary there but a lot of it is just the you take a risk when you hire someone from the outside where they
don't know the business they don't know the problems you're trying to solve so bringing this back around to your original question when it comes to you
know what are the backgrounds that that tend to suit people the best for this I think that the biggest traits that lend
themselves to people learning data science if they do need to upskill or resk or change direction tends to be
grit and tends to be logic so people being able to I mean when you start out
programming I know this was the case for me I imagine this may be the case for you as well programming for me was was
really hard um it was something where it took like three times of me learning to program for that to really click and I'm
not sure what it was I'm not sure what that mental block was for me but it was something that was really challenging
